author: Henry Stancu
title: Baby boom: Mountain gorilla comeback kids
text:
Photos View photos zoom Gorillas are revered in Rwanda.
The births of Rwandan mountain gorillas are cause for great celebration and this year marks a baby boom.
And it’s among best must-go-to geo tourism destinations in Africa.
The Rwanda Development Board hosts the eleventh Kwita Izina, a ceremony in which 24 baby gorillas are given names to the delight of thousands of locals and tourists who come to celebrate in Kigali.
The September 5th ceremony in Kinigi, at the foothills of the Virunga Mountains, about 100 km from the capital city of Kigali, and home to one of the planet’s once most critically endangered species of primates, marks a hopeful future for the gorillas and the Rwandan people.
“Gorilla naming is an important part of Rwanda’s conservation efforts,” said Ambassador Yamina Karitanyi, head of the country’s tourism and conservation department.
“The centuries-old tradition (of people naming their own newborns in a community celebration) now serves to play a significant role in the monitoring of each individual gorilla in their habitat and with their families.
“The Kwita Izina ceremony is a demonstration of the commitment to the conservation of Rwanda’s wildlife by the local communities, conservation groups, researchers, rangers, and tourists,” she added.
Rwanda is home to Africa’s largest mountain gorilla population, which has been steadily growing due to the country’s conservation efforts
Kwita Izina celebrates and names all of the known mountain gorillas born the previous year in Virunga National Park, and this year’s event includes a general census of the gorilla population. The last count was done in 2010 when the numbers of great apes had increased by about 26 per cent to 480 from about 380 over seven years.
By the 1970s the gorilla population had dwindled to about 250 due to poaching, disease and habitat loss by encroaching human settlement.
The theme for Kwita Izina 2015 is “Conserving Now and For the Future”. It has become an annual event based on a centuries-old Rwandan tradition that celebrates the birth of children. Family, friends, and neighbours hold a festive ceremony where mothers and father present their children and reveal the names they have chosen.
Held near the Volcanoes National Park’s headquarters, Kwita Izina caps a weeklong conservation festival, with events in Kigali and other locations in Rwanda. Baby gorillas are named by invited guests and then monitored for life by the park’s team of conservationists.
The baby gorillas are given names by various Rwandan dignitaries and also invited international guests, who have in the past included former President Bill Clinton, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, Hollywood actor Isaiah Washington and Nigerian film star Ramsey Tokunbo Nouah, among others.
Each baby gorilla’s name highlights the great importance of these treasured jungle creatures to this African nation and the world.
Kundurwanda (love Rwanda), Ndengera (protect me), Kwigira (self-resilience), Inzozi (dreams), Birashoboka (it is possible), Twiyubake (self-reliance), Gikundiro (likeable) and Ihoho (incomparable beauty), are some of the Rwandan names given to gorilla babies in the past.
Although the baby gorillas themselves are not present at the proceedings, a photograph of each is and the event is celebrated with traditional festivities and dances which have attracted as many as 40,000 people.
Besides visiting Volcanoes National Park for this major annual celebration, visitors can take in guided tours out of Kigali in the days leading up to the gorilla naming festival
It is the best time for tourists to visit Rwanda on a trip they can meet national park staff, noted conservationists, attend cultural evenings and a celebration in the tourist hub of Musanze, and tour the little-visited twin lakes Burero and Ruhondo, surrounded by the breathtaking landscape that is a wetland bird habitat and birder’s paradise.
The week leading up to the gorilla naming event also includes a business expo highlighting Rwanda’s economic growth and visits to Kinigi Cultural Center where locals exhibit and sell their products such as honey and handicrafts and offer interactive weaving workshops.
For more information on Kwita Izina and other activities in Rwanda, visit www.rwandatourism.com .
